Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Factors Contributing to the Efficacy of Mortgage-Based Homeownership Initiatives

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Since the post-war period, scholars and policy makers have understood homeownership to be a key factor in breaking the cycle of poverty. Indeed, the idea that owning a house confers enormous benefits on poor families, and that mortgages are the best way to do this, has become a central assumption in poverty-reduction strategies the world over. And yet, the 2007-2008 financial crisis in the United States crucially questioned whether homeownership was reliably a worthwhile goal for low-income families, who disproportionately suffered and lost in the crisis. This project, which trains a student in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, explores the extent to which homeownership is effective in breaking the cycle of poverty, and in what exact terms, is fundamental to the construction of effective policies that truly promote socioeconomic wellbeing. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology, findings will be disseminated to organizations and individuals exploring what factors promote or hinder families' ability to harness homeownership to break the cycle of poverty.

Inés Escobar Gonzalez, under the supervision of Dr. Stephan Palmié of the University of Chicago, explores what socioeconomic and cultural factors contribute to the success or failure of mortgage-based homeownership initiatives. The research will be conducted in Tlajomulco de Zúñiga, a municipality in the metropolitan area of Guadalajara in western Mexico. This is a particularly apt research setting because, since 2001, it has been the site of a government program that dramatically expanded mortgage-based homeownership rates amongst a diverse pool of lower-income families, resulting in various levels of case-based success. Therefore, the research setting will allow for a precise comparative study into the exact ways mortgages and mortgage-based homeownership are impacting the lives of different kinds of lower-income families, all while assessing the crucial explanatory variables that define people's ability to make and maintain assets. Based on a strategic comparative sample, the investigators will construct 36 case studies that comprise contrasting household structures, employment profiles, and income and asset histories, thus elucidating how different families are processually enabled and constrained by mortgage-based homeownership. The project will contribute to anthropological discussions about neoliberalism, economic anthropological debates about value and moral economies, and cross-disciplinary research on the relationship between debt, sociality, and property.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the 21st century, the development sector has embraced the “asset accumulation framework” as the most efficient and stable means of tackling global poverty and transforming the lives of people in materially lasting ways by, it is hoped, liberalizing credit and mobilizing successful investment. In the field of housing, policy-makers have relied on instruments seeking to expand homeownership amongst the urban poor via financial inclusion schemes. The main aim of this doctoral dissertation research was to empirically assess the extent to which government- and World Bank-subsidized mortgage-based homeownership programs attain their goal of enabling low-income households to build assets. This is an important task because, around the world, the liberalization of housing finance and the expansion of mortgage-based homeownership schemes have become equated with developmental strategy. And yet, at the time of this NSF award, the goal of universal homeownership, its feasibility, and its ground-level effects continued to be insufficiently examined by independent research beyond survey data.  

The research focused on the case of Mexico, a country that underwent a sweeping and World Bank-sanctioned housing finance reform in 2001, which, in brief, liberalized public and private mortgage credit to the degree that virtually every Mexican became entitled to a mortgage. The case was deemed apt for two reasons: first, the Mexican housing finance reform is representative of other reforms of its kind, as it followed accepted development sector guidelines and was considered a model for other developing economies seeking to expand homeownership; second, in benefitting 20 million people that occupied differentiable low-income brackets, the Mexican case offered a diverse enough sample to sustain case-based comparison, enabling the researchers to speak of, and differentiate within, the category “urban poor.” The outcomes that follow are based on the analysis of a strategic sample comprising 36 households (cases) inhabiting one of the largest housing developments emerging from the reform. The strategic sample included (a) mortgage-holding owner-occupiers (18); (b) tenants paying to occupy a house (6); (c) squatters and/or people living in lent houses (6), and (d) households that had vacated their property (6). The analysis is underpinned by 15 months of ethnographic participant-observation and sociological research.

The results do not support the thesis that holds mortgage-finance to be an effective and responsible means of breaking the cycle of poverty. In fact, we found that the majority of beneficiaries were further entrenched into poverty by the program. Within subsample (a), only a third of cases have not yet defaulted on the original loan. All of these successful cases held INFONAVIT mortgage loans; public-sector loans structured following government regulation guidelines, for which only formal-sector workers are eligible, and which are paid through installments automatically subtracted from the borrower’s paycheck. The remaining two thirds of subsample (a), unsuccessful cases, held private subprime mortgage loans and were informal-sector workers (an unsurprising coincidence given that informal-sector workers were only eligible for private loans). The private subprime loans at stake were all issued by a handful of (thinly capitalized) mortgage lending companies that were set up by construction companies in time for the reform.

There are three reasons for the lack of success of two thirds of subsample (a): 1) the beneficiaries of subprime mortgage loans had low, unprotected, and unstable informal-sector incomes, and they were not sufficiently screened to determine their repayment capacity; 2) the extreme floating interest rates meant that beneficiaries could not afford to make principal contributions; and 3) when the mortgage lending companies declared bankruptcy and stopped serving their borrowers from 2014 onwards, the beneficiaries’ loans were not restructured to reestablish certainty. What has ensued, and was corroborated by the complementary analysis of subsamples (b), (c), and (d), is a rapid informalization of property relations. Bolstered by the critical legal ambiguity observable throughout the housing development, there is now a thriving property black market that has contributed towards insecurity, violence, and severe rent inflation. In a word, the program has failed, as it has not enabled the critical mass of beneficiaries to build assets and has indeed pushed them into further debt cycles.

Based on our findings, we recommend the development sector and participant countries build regulatory infrastructure to ensure resources are spent in more effective development mechanisms. The financial, banking, and construction sectors must be better regulated if they are to become allies of (real) development. Subprime mortgage loans are not a poverty alleviator, and do not result in asset construction. Furthermore, publically sponsored mortgage-based homeownership programs must act in conjunction with political economic measures that actually increase people’s income security. Finally, as the world’s poorest suffer progressive precarization, development banks and governments must reconsider the recuperation and improvement of not-for-sale public housing schemes. The households that make up this study would have been better equipped to productively spend their income had their right to housing, not “homeownership,” been upheld.
